VH.

Octavius Rufus was an intimate friend of Pliny, and ac- cording to him a poet of no mean merit. Cf. ii. 10, where Pliny urges him to publish his poems. The Baetici (in the south-east of Spain) were prosecuting Gallus, and were desirous of obtaining as their advocate Pliny, who had always been their friend. On the other hand Gallus seeks through Octavius Rufus either to obtain Pliny’s advocacy, or, failing that, his neutrality. Pliny here replies, refusing to appear for Gallus, but at the same time promising not to appear for the Baetici.
